headers.subject: Re: Problems Firefox 3.5.2 media version
headers.user-agent: Mozilla/5.0 (OS/2; U; Warp 4.5; en-US; rv:1.9.1.3pre) Gecko/20090813 SeaMonkey/2.0b2pre
headers.x-abuse-and-dmca-info: Please be sure to forward a copy of ALL headers
Otherwise we will be unable to process your complaint properly
headers.list-id: The OS/2 ports of Mozilla products <dev-ports-os2.lists.mozilla.org>

quote.quotepara: On Mon, 10 Aug 2009 03:47:29 UTC, Dave Yeo<dave.r.yeo@gmail.com> wrote:

Now that it's been up ten hours (in use about four of those hours), it's becoming unusable due to 6-10 second "pauses" where the system freezes/is unresponsive (and nothing typed in a field is echoed, no scrolling can occur), then is usuable again for another 20-50 seconds.
Is your CPU peaking during those freezes? Dave
I am experiencing the same behaviour, however I am using the 'vanilla' 3.5.2 release.

My machine runs 24/7...previously, when using 3.0.10 I would usually have to re-boot after a 7 day run...otherwise eventually I would get some kind of a lock-up or a number of SYS3175s. The improvement with 3.5.2 appears to be vast in terms of overall system stability, I am now on Day12 of uptime...with solid everyday use of the PC.

The marked difference between 3.0.10& 3.5.2 is that within about 2-3 days the browser develops this 'delay' behaviour. When I click on a link, the CPU goes to 100%, stays there for some time (the duration varies, I have not been able to determine what causes it), eventually the new link is opened. The delay gets progressively worse the longer the browser has been up and running.

body.para: This is basically what I've experienced for quite a while with Seamonkey v2, which is the same codebase as Firefox 3.5.x. All I can think of is some kind of garbage collection going on Dave
